The use of "memory" and "storage" in the video is the most popular, but is not universal. Von Neumann liked to use biological terms like "memory" and "organs" when describing computers but many people preferred "storage" and "subsystems" to avoid misleading analogies. IBM often (but not always) used "storage" to mean the same things that other companies called "memory".
You fool. You absolute potato.

"Unpunching a hole is hard", but far from impossible. My university was still using punch cards in 1980 (replaced with terminals the following year) and the lines for the punch machines would get silly near course deadlines. So I had a bag of holes collected from the punch machines (on days they weren't so busy), a razor and one reference card with all the characters punched in it. Adding a few holes and eliminating a few from a card could be done in a minute instead of waiting hours in line for a free machine.

😎 Example Time Scale of System Latencies (Gregg 2013 Systems Performance): https://twitter.com/piecalculus/status/459485747842523136?lang=en  What you're looking at are the real world latencies of system components and an example scale where the shortest instance is one second long.

Re: SAGE program at 1:20 - I worked on ASUPT - Advanced Simulator for Undergraduate Pilot Training - which the US Air Force brought on line in 1973. It was the first flight simulator to have a computer generated visual display. The computers (there were three) had core memory, mag tapes, and a disk drive with a stack of nine interchangeable 12 inch metal plates. It was programmed on cards in a combination of FORTRAN and the dialect of assembly for that machine. I don't recall the exact number of cards in the total load, but I seem to remember it was more than the 63500 you quoted for SAGE.   For what it's worth, the research we did on that machine to find out the best way to use simulators for pilot training led directly to the simulators used by airlines today to train their pilots and run annual emergency procedure check rides (think practicing engine out landings).

In a card reader either a light shines on the card with sensors on the other side detecting the holes or little wires make contact through the card to a metal plate on the other side. The optical card readers stress the cards less, but even the electrical ones do essentially no damage at all. Moving the card around with mechanical rollers probably hurts them more than the actual reading of the data.  Note that though some card readers were shown in the video, most of the machines that were seen with cards were punch machines where you type on a keyboard and it makes the little holes in the first place.

By the time we get to the Herman Hollerith's tabulator used in the US 1890 Census the cards were being read electrically. Were punch card sequences like the SAGE program not numbered? Efficient sorting algorithms existed at the time, so that would make it lot easier to return the cards in order in case of an accident. Googling trying to find it, it seems the Arduino crowd are still toying with the idea, just because of the silliness of it -- I mean, you could put a full Arduino system with a multiple-terabyte SSD in a VHS tape's shell. Something that should be noted about SSDs is that they're different from normal ICs in that the storage process involves essentially pushing electrons with really high force into and out of materials with really high resistance. The resulting electrostatic fields turn field effect transistors on or off, without needing moving electrons.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flash_memory#NAND_flash  To greatly oversimplify, they use the classic gates we saw earlier in this series, but with a type of transistor that has resistive material around it, holding the charge "in place" unless a stronger charge overwrites it.

Solid state memory (e.g. flash memory) uses a floating gate transistor to trap electrons. There are lots of videos on youtube how it exactly works (it's technical and requires "quantum tunneling".  But it's non-volatile because once the electrons are trapped, you don't need to supply power to retain the memory.
Matthew Hoiland Take a look at a product description of a modern SSD. It probably says NAND flash somewhere :D

The limitations of SSD technology include taking more energy and time to WRITE than to READ (like paper and pencil), and gradually "wearing out" individual cells on a chip after many write cycles. This is why SSDs are not defragmented; they don't NEED it, and it requires repeated write cycles to copy files from one set of cells to another.

They use a system of nand gates.   It causes way things line up, to get flipped, because of inverters and stuff... I don't really remember though, but it's like how sand stays in the same place once you stop pushing it...  ...it isn't truly non-volatile, just like how wind and earth tremors can mess with my pretty sand shapes:   Quantum chaos can gradually alter the way semiconductors are charged, untils 1s become 0s and so on.   It's called "bit-rot" it's the bane of retro games' collectors.  But in that sense: nothing is truly non-volatile.  It works, so we use it. Inks can fade, cylinders can wear down, vinyl gets scratched, so on an so forth.

DOS and Windows were once distributed on sets of diskettes (the "official" term for floppy disks), and early PCs used a floppy to load DOS into RAM, then a different floppy to hold user programs and data. Most of them later used a second floppy drive so that more data could be online at the same time. Since the first floppy drive was labeled A:, the second became B:, and when hard drives were introduced, the first hard day so drive was called C:, which is why most PCs today have no A: or B: drive. CD-ROM came along later, as did flash drives, so all new forms of removable storage are assigned letters starting with D:.

I have 4 HDD's and a DVD-RW drive... (no SSD though). no floppy drive mostly because MOBO's stopped having the connector.  when I was young, there were 5.25" floppies (older tech), and 3.5" (more common).  I think CD-RW never really lived up to the promise, as it was typically used "write once" or "append onto the end until full", as erasing the discs was too slow to really make it really worthwhile (and then one may as well just use the cheaper CD-R discs).   I thought floppies were mostly dead for years, until recently encountering people who are still using them... (with USB floppy drives sticky-taped to the computers).  though, wander out and one might encounter equipment still in use using orange-on-black CRT displays with a blinky text UI and having an internal storage space small enough to where the entire machine can be dumped onto a floppy...
I remember 8" floppies. God I'm gettin old.

Yup, my high school newspaper used 8" floppies in whatever ancient typesetting computer they had.  (This was in the early '90s, so 3.5" floppies were the norm.) You'd type your article on one ancient computer, save it to the 8" floppy disk, then transfer it over to the computerized typesetting and printing system that had been donated sometime in the late '70s.  Thankfully, the yearbook got a then-brand-new Macintosh Quadra for yearbook use. We even had a color scanner, and could typeset with the actual pictures right on the computer! No placeholders to be done optically at the printers! (Of course, that means that my senior yearbook had much lower quality photos in it, since they were scanned then sent to the printer, rather than shipping them the physical hard copy photos that they would duplicate optically.)  We did do the student portraits and some other sections with placeholders-and-optical-transfer. But for the "student life" sections, we could get more creative on the computer with early versions of Photoshop and Pagemaker.
